title: They're increasing the time that an assassin needs to kill you
body: doesn't that mean that talon can have his silence back? since it was removed because of instant burst+silence

replies.body: No, to the contrary. They want to increase the time an assassin needs to kill you to open up opportunities of counter-play. A silence would remove any possibility of counter-play.

Yup. A silence on a melee champion with a much longer kill time, or much more limited target accessibility would be fine (e.g. Garen). You're right, but it gets tricky when considering what assassins should be good at.  If Riot lowers the speed of their kills, they'll likely have to put other systems in their kits, which have historically been abused by tank builds (Tank Ekko, Tank Akali, Tank Kat back in the day).  

Additionally, I think Riot far undervalues the importance of a fast kill in a teamfight.  Even if the assassin trades 1 for 1, if they prevent their opponent from doing their job, the fight is still 5 contributions vs 4 contributions.  In terms of surviving champs, it looks like a 4v4, but if you go consider cooldowns and how the fight plays out, it's still largely successful for assassins to "fail" and go 1-for-1.  

But 1-for-1 isn't what I'm worried about, it's when Riot gives these champs resets (Kat), sustain (Akali), CC (Ekko), etc.  Player feel aside, I honestly think one-kill-and-done burst assassins are healthier than the Ekko/Akali/Kat's of the world.

Well my point at the end of the day is this:

league of legends is to some extent an economic problem. 
The economy of the game necessitates an ADC.
Therefore a lot of champions are defined primarily through their ability to pursue and kill the ADC, or through their ability to protect one. 

So many champions who's "gameplay fantasy" is "I do X and the enemy ADC dies" exist that you get a whole class of champions who's game-play is basically "everybody kills you", a second class of champions who's gameplay is biased towards "go peel for him", and a fairly narrow way of playing the game in which some items 
{{item:3153}} {{item:3146}} {{item:3078}} are "fun" and some are just not {{item:3050}} {{item:3143}} {{item:3222}} . 

The leading competitor (DOTA2) has a much broader definition of what champions should be doing, resulting in a much broader range or strategies. There are a bunch of very clever design decisions in DOTA2, but one of the chief ones is the economy of the game being set up such that having a ranged ADC on the team is not a win condition.

But having a carry is a necessity.

Riot's problem is primarily that no other champs have been able to successfully play the role of carry. There isn't a single DotA2 game where a carry isn't involved in some way, shape, or form - it just so happens that in League of Legends we don't have an applicable melee champ (or champs) that can take the role.

0cs supports exist in DotA2 as well. The mechanics you described are all that, except the word ADC is just replaced with carry. There's a reason supports like Oracle that can make you stop taking damage or be immune to magic damage are strong... or supports like Shadow Demon who can disrupt the carry to protect them from damage. The mechanics are very, very similar to League mechanics - the role just doesn't include "ranged", only "carry". But a carry is still 100% necessary, and a physical damage carry is highly preferred.

Your first point is applicable to DOTA's meta, but it isn't objectively true.

In games like Halo, or hell, any sport in the history of ever, is it required that you have one person be far more impactful to the game than anyone else?  HELL NO.  And it would make no sense to try to change them otherwise.  

I've personally always hated the idea of a carry in a multiplayer game, as they are basically and fundamentally gamewarping.  

League (and probably DOTA, though that is a game I am much less experienced with) would be a much more interesting, and imo a much more balanced and fun game if every class of champion and every champion in each class had exactly the same game impact as everyone else.  It should be much more like: 'Tanks should counter mages, who should blow up  squishies who should melt tanks' than ADCs are the be-all-end-all of the game that are necessitated in every game, and have been balanced around for 5, almost 6 years now, and every other role is directly related to the ADC and how they interact with them.  e.g. tanks and supports peel for their ADC while trying to CC the enemy.  Bruisers and assassin's try to dive the enemy ADC and kill the ASAP and mages try to nuke the carries, and settle for AoEing the divers, or the peelers if they can't reach their target.

What's wonderful about carries in DotA2 is that they don't always work the way you're accustomed to in League, and their curve is MUCH harder than a League carries. A large percentage of DotA2 carries absolutely cannot be left alone in lane unless the laner is specifically a matchup that can't kill them - and because of deny mechanics it's much easier to make a carry miss CS. Due to how scaling works in DotA2 (it's much harder to increase the damage of your abilities outright in a meaningful way), a physical damage carry will eventually be required. But that physical damage carry can be any number of carries, all of whom work in completely different ways. I mean, Phantom Assassin and Anti-Mage are both carries, but they function in very different ways, and both of them function differently from Spectre.

To illustrate:
Phantom Assassin carries hard because her ultimate is a steroid that gives her one of the highest damage crits in the game. She generally utilizes this in tandem with her blink to attempt to quickly jump to a target and kill them before they can react - she plays much more like an assassin than a traditional carry. Her blink however needs a target, so her escape options are limited in comparison to her engage options. She works great with teams with a lot of hard engage or who have another damage threat that may need to be focused down, allowing her to destroy the backline.

Anti-Mage takes reduced damage from nukes and has a blink on a very short CD. Additionally, he drains mana with his AAs (and can nuke you with damage that increases based on missing mana). Anti-Mage is fairly weak early (needs a lot of levels in all of his skills on top of items to scale into a damage threat, though cheesy level 6 kills are not impossible and he's hard to gank). He's a very strong splitpusher and can 1v1 people very easily. Anti-Mage generally spends the early part of the game pushing a lane until battlefury and then utilizing his blink to quickly farm in the jungle (blinking between camps and into lanes to accelerate his farming speed). He can work great with push comps because he can quickly rotate to fights and splitpush easily.

Spectre is a carry who literally carries by standing in the middle of the enemy team. She generally is fairly weak until 2-3 items, but you also generally build items like Radiance (a damage item that functions similar to Sunfire) and utilizing her second ability, which reduces a percentage of the damage she takes and deals that damage to the units around her (higher damage to closer units). She also has a global ultimate that creates copies of herself (which can use her Radiance burn), and she can choose to teleport to one of the illusions. Spectre is generally very good when your team lacks a tanky frontliner but has initiation tools or ways to assist you in setting up fights or picks.

None of these carries carry in the same way. They all operate completely differently, and different items are good on them, but they're ALL agility carries.

DotA2 has the right idea - carries that all function differently and work best with different kinds of teams. In League it feels a bit one-size-fits-all, which I think is why we only really see 2-3 carries in the spotlight at any given time.

from the support side, how about we talk Lina here? what kind of support in league can 100-0 the enemy mid-lane? what kind of damage oriented mid lane champion can go support with success?

Whereas in DOTA2 yes you call faceless void a carry but honestly when your carry can just ult the enemy top lane and 1v1 me bro with just a little bit of extra damage from the support you're not playing the same game.

faceless void hasn't been a hard carry for a few patches now.

The major difference is that instead of having melee carries (Yi, Fiora, Tryn, etc) and ranged carries (ashe, ez, jinx, jhin, etc), where one is considered the "hard carry" because of their necessity for pushing towers (generally the ranged carry), in DotA2 a "semi-carry" (the equivalent of the melee carries above) is what someone like Tiny, Void, or Templar Assassin would be - characters without a traditional steroid (they don't have Drow Ranger's 80 AGI for free or Troll Warlord's tons of ASPD passives and ult), but who can be built to dish out significant physical damage. They generally can also be built in a more utility role (templar assassin being a great example of someone who can provide primarily utility and pick-potential or who can be your primary source of physical damage).

You can't directly compare the classes for two games that are completely different.

They should do what they did with Kalista and make it so bonus armor and MR are less effective on assassins, but make up for it by giving them more power or utility. That way you stop them from buying tank items and reward them for buying assassin items.

imo, that was an awful design choice. How much AD does a BF sword add to your AA? 40 for every champion but i hope you remembered the exception. That solution lacked clarity and does nothing but obfuscate the effectiveness of items. Instead of memorizing just how much stats an item gives you have to remember a matrix of how much stats each item gives for every champ. The burden of knowledge that kind of variable scaling yields to is too damn high (insert meme here).

Kalista is not the only exception. Graves also has an AD ratio on his basic attacks, Corky had one until recently, Kog'maw has one in mini-gun mode. And more generally, ratios on basic attacks are rather common. Ashe and Jhin have a Crit/Crit chance ratio, Graves and Jhin have an AS ratio.

You can argue it's a bad choice in all of those cases, but I think it opens up an interesting design space.

I forgot about graves, i'm not entirely sure how i feel about his ratio because they are weird and i'll have to look into it more. 

I would argue that removing corki's ratio was a good thing, he was dominant with a 1.1 ratio and when that got nerfed he fell back in line. Successive corki nerfs have had him weak for a while now so we'll see what happens with him. 

Koggers is an ability and that isn't as bad, like with jinx getting extra damage on rockets it costs mana and does more damage like an ability should. 

Crit chance (even if guaranteed in certain circumstances) is an on hit effect and is different than the base damage done on autos. Ashe for instance interacts with crit differently from others but that's different from scaling off bonus ad differently.

My point was: it's relatively common that buying the same item on different markspeople does not scale their basic attacks the same way.

You can say that Crit is an on-hit and everything, but look at what buying Crit items does for Ashe, and you'll see it's exactly the same thing as what you were complaining about with Kalista.

"How much DPS does an IE add to your AA?" Well, it depends, not the same if you are Ashe.

So I certainly agree with you that it's not perfect in terms of clarity. But saying that "it's an awful design choice", that's quite a bit stronger, and I disagree with that.

Also, regarding Corky, you mentioned power levels, but that's a completely different topic. Current Kalista would probably be OP if you removed the passive all of a sudden, and that doesn't prove this kind of ratios are a good thing, no more than removing it from Corky and making him balanced proved it was a good thing.

Ratio on AA are just yet another balance lever among many. The important question, the one we started to discuss in the beginning, is: is it a good/useful lever, or does it have too many drawbacks (e.g. clarity/burden of knowledge, etc.)? For me it's a good lever, and the problem you mentioned isn't really a problem, since all other abilities already have a ratio, so this kind of variability in the value of a given stat between different champions already exist. But that's an open question, I certainly don't know the absolute truth.
